# Antibody

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about the class of proteins. For other uses, see [Antibody
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Antibody_\(disambiguation\) "Antibody
\(disambiguation\)").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Antibody.svg/255px-
Antibody.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Antibody.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Antibody.svg "Enlarge")

Each antibody binds to a specific [antigen](/wiki/Antigen "Antigen"); an
interaction similar to a lock and key.

An **antibody** (**Ab**), also known as an **immunoglobulin** (**Ig**),[1] is
a large, Y-shaped [protein](/wiki/Protein "Protein") produced mainly by
[plasma cells](/wiki/Plasma_cell "Plasma cell") that is used by the [immune
system](/wiki/Immune_system "Immune system") to neutralize
[pathogens](/wiki/Pathogen "Pathogen") such as [pathogenic
bacteria](/wiki/Pathogenic_bacteria "Pathogenic bacteria") and
[viruses](/wiki/Viral_disease "Viral disease"). The antibody recognizes a
unique molecule of the pathogen, called an [antigen](/wiki/Antigen "Antigen"),
via the [Fab's variable region](/wiki/Fragment_antigen-binding "Fragment
antigen-binding").[2][3] Each tip of the "Y" of an antibody contains a
[paratope](/wiki/Paratope "Paratope") (analogous to a lock) that is specific
for one particular [epitope](/wiki/Epitope "Epitope") (similarly analogous to
a key) on an antigen, allowing these two structures to bind together with
precision. Using this binding mechanism, an antibody can _tag_ a
[microbe](/wiki/Microbe "Microbe") or an infected cell for attack by other
parts of the immune system, or can neutralize its target directly (for
example, by blocking a part of a microbe that is essential for its invasion
and survival). Depending on the antigen, the binding may impede the biological
process causing the disease or may activate [macrophages](/wiki/Macrophages
"Macrophages") to destroy the foreign substance. The ability of an antibody to
communicate with the other components of the immune system is mediated via its
[Fc region](/wiki/Fragment_crystallizable_region "Fragment crystallizable
region") (located at the base of the "Y"), which contains a conserved
[glycosylation](/wiki/Glycosylation "Glycosylation") site involved in these
interactions.[4] The production of antibodies is the main function of the
[humoral immune system](/wiki/Humoral_immune_system "Humoral immune
system").[5]

Antibodies are secreted by [B cells](/wiki/B_cell "B cell") of the adaptive
immune system, mostly by differentiated B cells called [plasma
cells](/wiki/Plasma_cell "Plasma cell"). Antibodies can occur in two physical
forms, a soluble form that is secreted from the cell to be free in the [blood
plasma](/wiki/Blood_plasma "Blood plasma"), and a
[membrane](/wiki/Cell_membrane "Cell membrane")-bound form that is attached to
the surface of a B cell and is referred to as the [B-cell
receptor](/wiki/B-cell_receptor "B-cell receptor") (BCR). The BCR is found
only on the surface of B cells and facilitates the activation of these cells
and their subsequent differentiation into either antibody factories called
[plasma cells](/wiki/Plasma_cell "Plasma cell") or [memory B
cells](/wiki/Memory_B_cell "Memory B cell") that will survive in the body and
remember that same antigen so the B cells can respond faster upon future
exposure.[6] In most cases, interaction of the B cell with a [T helper
cell](/wiki/T_cell "T cell") is necessary to produce full activation of the B
cell and, therefore, antibody generation following antigen binding.[7] Soluble
antibodies are released into the [blood](/wiki/Blood "Blood") and tissue
fluids, as well as many [secretions](/wiki/Secretion "Secretion") to continue
to survey for invading microorganisms.

Antibodies are [glycoproteins](/wiki/Glycoprotein "Glycoprotein") belonging to
the [immunoglobulin superfamily](/wiki/Immunoglobulin_superfamily
"Immunoglobulin superfamily").[4] They constitute most of the [gamma
globulin](/wiki/Gamma_globulin "Gamma globulin") fraction of the [blood
proteins](/wiki/Blood_proteins "Blood proteins"). They are typically made of
basic structural units—each with two large [heavy
chains](/wiki/Immunoglobulin_heavy_chain "Immunoglobulin heavy chain") and two
small [light chains](/wiki/Immunoglobulin_light_chain "Immunoglobulin light
chain"). There are several different types of antibody heavy chains that
define the five different types of crystallisable fragments (Fc) that may be
attached to the antigen-binding fragments. The five different types of Fc
regions allow antibodies to be grouped into five
_[isotypes](/wiki/Isotype_\(immunology\) "Isotype \(immunology\)")_. Each Fc
region of a particular antibody isotype is able to bind to its specific Fc
Receptor (except for IgD, which is essentially the BCR), thus allowing the
antigen-antibody complex to mediate different roles depending on which FcR it
binds. The ability of an antibody to bind to its corresponding FcR is further
modulated by the structure of the glycan(s) present at conserved sites within
its Fc region.[4] The ability of antibodies to bind to FcRs helps to direct
the appropriate immune response for each different type of foreign object they
encounter.[8] For example, [IgE](/wiki/IgE "IgE") is responsible for an
[allergic](/wiki/Allergic "Allergic") response consisting of [mast
cell](/wiki/Mast_cell "Mast cell") degranulation and
[histamine](/wiki/Histamine "Histamine") release. IgE's
[Fab](/wiki/Fragment_antigen-binding "Fragment antigen-binding") paratope
binds to allergic [antigen](/wiki/Antigen "Antigen"), for example [house dust
mite](/wiki/House_dust_mite "House dust mite") particles, while its Fc region
binds to Fc receptor ε. The allergen-IgE-FcRε interaction mediates allergic
signal transduction to induce conditions such as asthma.[9]

Though the general structure of all antibodies is very similar, a small region
at the tip of the protein is extremely variable, allowing millions of
antibodies with slightly different tip structures, or antigen-binding sites,
to exist. This region is known as the _hypervariable region_. Each of these
variants can bind to a different antigen.[2] This enormous diversity of
antibody paratopes on the antigen-binding fragments allows the immune system
to recognize an equally wide variety of antigens.[1] The large and diverse
population of antibody paratope is generated by random recombination events of
a set of [gene](/wiki/Gene "Gene") segments that encode different antigen-
binding sites (or _paratopes_), followed by random [mutations](/wiki/Mutation
"Mutation") in this area of the antibody gene, which create further
diversity.[8][10] This recombinational process that produces clonal antibody
paratope diversity is called V(D)J or VJ recombination. Basically, the
antibody paratope is polygenic, made up of three genes, V, D, and J. Each
paratope locus is also polymorphic, such that during antibody production, one
allele of V, one of D, and one of J is chosen. These gene segments are then
joined together using random genetic recombination to produce the paratope.
The regions where the genes are randomly recombined together is the hyper
variable region used to recognise different antigens on a clonal basis.

Antibody genes also re-organize in a process called [class
switching](/wiki/Immunoglobulin_class_switching "Immunoglobulin class
switching") that changes the one type of heavy chain Fc fragment to another,
creating a different isotype of the antibody that retains the antigen-specific
variable region. This allows a single antibody to be used by different types
of Fc receptors, expressed on different parts of the immune system.

## Forms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Forms")]

The membrane-bound form of an antibody may be called a _surface
immunoglobulin_ (sIg) or a _membrane immunoglobulin_ (mIg). It is part of the
_B cell receptor_ (BCR), which allows a B cell to detect when a specific
antigen is present in the body and triggers B cell activation.[11] The BCR is
composed of surface-bound IgD or IgM antibodies and associated Ig-α and Ig-β
[heterodimers](/wiki/Heterodimer "Heterodimer"), which are capable of [signal
transduction](/wiki/Signal_transduction "Signal transduction").[12] A typical
human B cell will have 50,000 to 100,000 antibodies bound to its surface.[12]
Upon antigen binding, they cluster in large patches, which can exceed 1
micrometer in diameter, on lipid rafts that isolate the BCRs from most other
cell signaling receptors.[12] These patches may improve the efficiency of the
[cellular immune response](/wiki/Cell-mediated_immunity "Cell-mediated
immunity").[13] In humans, the cell surface is bare around the B cell
receptors for several hundred nanometers,[12] which further isolates the BCRs
from competing influences.

## Antibody–antigen
interactions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Antibody–antigen interactions")]

The antibody's paratope interacts with the antigen's epitope. An antigen
usually contains different epitopes along its surface arranged
discontinuously, and dominant epitopes on a given antigen are called
determinants.

Antibody and antigen interact by spatial complementarity (lock and key). The
molecular forces involved in the Fab-epitope interaction are weak and non-
specific – for example [electrostatic forces](/wiki/Coulomb%27s_law "Coulomb's
law"), [hydrogen bonds](/wiki/Hydrogen_bond "Hydrogen bond"), [hydrophobic
interactions](/wiki/Hydrophobic_interactions "Hydrophobic interactions"), and
[van der Waals forces](/wiki/Van_der_Waals_force "Van der Waals force"). This
means binding between antibody and antigen is reversible, and the antibody's
[affinity](/wiki/Affinity_\(pharmacology\) "Affinity \(pharmacology\)")
towards an antigen is relative rather than absolute. Relatively weak binding
also means it is possible for an antibody to cross-react with different
antigens of different relative affinities.

Often, once an antibody and antigen bind, they become an [immune
complex](/wiki/Immune_complex "Immune complex"), which functions as a unitary
object and can act as an antigen in its own right, being countered by other
antibodies. Similarly, [haptens](/wiki/Hapten "Hapten") are small molecules
that provoke no immune response by themselves, but once they bind to proteins,
the resulting complex or hapten-carrier [adduct](/wiki/Adduct "Adduct") is
antigenic.

## Isotypes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Isotypes")]

Antibodies can come in different varieties known as
[isotypes](/wiki/Isotype_\(immunology\) "Isotype \(immunology\)") or classes.
In [placental](/wiki/Eutheria "Eutheria") mammals there are five antibody
isotypes known as IgA, IgD, IgE, IgG, and IgM. They are each named with an
"Ig" prefix that stands for immunoglobulin, a name sometimes used
interchangeably with antibody, and differ in their biological properties,
functional locations and ability to deal with different antigens, as depicted
in the table.[14] The different suffixes of the antibody isotypes denote the
different types of heavy chains the antibody contains, with each heavy chain
class named alphabetically: α (alpha), γ (gamma), δ (delta), ε (epsilon), and
μ (mu). This gives rise to IgA, IgG, IgD, IgE, and IgM, respectively.

Antibody isotypes of mammals Name | Types | Description | Antibody complexes  
---|---|---|---  
[IgA](/wiki/IgA "IgA") | 2 | Found in [mucosal](/wiki/Mucosal "Mucosal") areas, such as the [gut](/wiki/Gut_\(zoology\) "Gut \(zoology\)"), [respiratory tract](/wiki/Respiratory_tract "Respiratory tract") and [urogenital tract](/wiki/Urogenital_tract "Urogenital tract"), and prevents colonization by [pathogens](/wiki/Pathogen "Pathogen").[15] Also found in saliva, tears, and breast milk. | [![Some antibodies form complexes that bind to multiple antigen molecules.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Mono-und-Polymere.svg/170px-Mono-und-Polymere.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Mono-und-Polymere.svg "Some antibodies form complexes that bind to multiple antigen molecules.")  
[IgD](/wiki/IgD "IgD") | 1 | Functions mainly as an [antigen](/wiki/Antigen "Antigen") receptor on B cells that have not been exposed to antigens.[16] It has been shown to activate [basophils](/wiki/Basophil "Basophil") and [mast cells](/wiki/Mast_cell "Mast cell") to produce [antimicrobial](/wiki/Antimicrobial "Antimicrobial") factors.[17]  
[IgE](/wiki/IgE "IgE") | 1 | Binds to [allergens](/wiki/Allergen "Allergen") and triggers [histamine](/wiki/Histamine "Histamine") release from [mast cells](/wiki/Mast_cell "Mast cell") and [basophils](/wiki/Basophil "Basophil"), and is involved in [allergy](/wiki/Allergy "Allergy"). Also protects against [parasitic worms](/wiki/Parasitic_worm "Parasitic worm").[5]  
[IgG](/wiki/IgG "IgG") | 4 | In its four forms, provides the majority of antibody-based immunity against invading pathogens.[5] The only antibody capable of crossing the [placenta](/wiki/Placenta "Placenta") to give passive immunity to the [fetus](/wiki/Fetus "Fetus").  
[IgM](/wiki/IgM "IgM") | 1 | Expressed on the surface of B cells (monomer) and in a secreted form (pentamer) with very high [avidity](/wiki/Avidity "Avidity"). Eliminates pathogens in the early stages of B cell-mediated (humoral) immunity before there is sufficient IgG.[5][16]  
  
The antibody isotype of a [B cell](/wiki/B_cell "B cell") changes during cell
[development](/wiki/Pre-pre_B_cell "Pre-pre B cell") and activation. Immature
B cells, which have never been exposed to an antigen, express only the IgM
isotype in a cell surface bound form. The B lymphocyte, in this ready-to-
respond form, is known as a "naive B lymphocyte." The naive B lymphocyte
expresses both surface IgM and IgD. The co-expression of both of these
immunoglobulin isotypes renders the B cell ready to respond to antigen.[18] B
cell activation follows engagement of the cell-bound antibody molecule with an
antigen, causing the cell to divide and
[differentiate](/wiki/Cellular_differentiation "Cellular differentiation")
into an antibody-producing cell called a [plasma cell](/wiki/Plasma_cell
"Plasma cell"). In this activated form, the B cell starts to produce antibody
in a [secreted](/wiki/Secretion "Secretion") form rather than a
[membrane](/wiki/Cell_membrane "Cell membrane")-bound form. Some [daughter
cells](/wiki/Daughter_cell "Daughter cell") of the activated B cells undergo
[isotype switching](/wiki/Isotype_switching "Isotype switching"), a mechanism
that causes the production of antibodies to change from IgM or IgD to the
other antibody isotypes, IgE, IgA, or IgG, that have defined roles in the
immune system.

Antibody isotypes not found in mammals Name | Types | Description  
---|---|---  
[IgY](/wiki/Immunoglobulin_Y "Immunoglobulin Y") |  | Found in [birds](/wiki/Bird "Bird") and [reptiles](/wiki/Reptile "Reptile"); related to mammalian [IgG](/wiki/IgG "IgG").[19]  
IgW |  | Found in [sharks and skates](/wiki/Elasmobranchii "Elasmobranchii"); related to mammalian IgD.[20]  
  
## Structure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Structure")]

Antibodies are heavy (~150 k[Da](/wiki/Dalton_\(unit\) "Dalton \(unit\)"))
[globular](/wiki/Globular_protein "Globular protein") [plasma
proteins](/wiki/Plasma_protein "Plasma protein"). They have sugar chains
(glycans) added to conserved [amino acid](/wiki/Amino_acid "Amino acid")
residues.[4][21] In other words, antibodies are
_[glycoproteins](/wiki/Glycoprotein "Glycoprotein")_.[4] The attached glycans
are critically important to the structure and function of the antibody.[4]
Among other things the expressed glycans can modulate an antibody's affinity
for its corresponding FcR(s).[4]

The basic functional unit of each antibody is an immunoglobulin (Ig)
[monomer](/wiki/Monomer "Monomer") (containing only one Ig unit); secreted
antibodies can also be [dimeric](/wiki/Protein_dimer "Protein dimer") with two
Ig units as with IgA, [tetrameric](/wiki/Tetramer_protein "Tetramer protein")
with four Ig units like [teleost fish](/wiki/Teleost_fish "Teleost fish") IgM,
or [pentameric](/wiki/Pentamer "Pentamer") with five Ig units, like mammalian
IgM.[22]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Antibody_IgG2.png/220px-
Antibody_IgG2.png)](/wiki/File:Antibody_IgG2.png)

[](/wiki/File:Antibody_IgG2.png "Enlarge")

Several immunoglobulin domains make up the two heavy chains (red and blue) and
the two light chains (green and yellow) of an antibody. The immunoglobulin
domains are composed of between 7 (for constant domains) and 9 (for variable
domains) [β-strands](/wiki/%CE%92-strand "Β-strand").

The variable parts of an antibody are its V regions, and the constant part is
its C region.

### Immunoglobulin
domains[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Immunoglobulin domains")]

The Ig monomer is a "Y"-shaped molecule that consists of four
[polypeptide](/wiki/Polypeptide "Polypeptide") chains; two identical _heavy
chains_ and two identical _light chains_ connected by [disulfide
bonds](/wiki/Disulfide_bond "Disulfide bond").[14] Each chain is composed of
[structural domains](/wiki/Structural_domain "Structural domain") called
[immunoglobulin domains](/wiki/Immunoglobulin_domain "Immunoglobulin domain").
These domains contain about 70–110 [amino acids](/wiki/Amino_acid "Amino
acid") and are classified into different categories (for example, variable or
IgV, and constant or IgC) according to their size and function.[23] They have
a characteristic [immunoglobulin fold](/wiki/Immunoglobulin_fold
"Immunoglobulin fold") in which two [beta sheets](/wiki/Beta_sheet "Beta
sheet") create a "sandwich" shape, held together by interactions between
conserved [cysteines](/wiki/Cysteine "Cysteine") and other charged amino
acids.

### Heavy chain[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Heavy chain")]

For more details on this topic, see [Immunoglobulin heavy
chain](/wiki/Immunoglobulin_heavy_chain "Immunoglobulin heavy chain").

There are five types of mammalian Ig [heavy
chain](/wiki/Immunoglobulin_heavy_chain "Immunoglobulin heavy chain") denoted
by the [Greek letters](/wiki/Greek_letters "Greek letters"): [α](/wiki/%CE%91
"Α"), [δ](/wiki/%CE%94 "Δ"), [ε](/wiki/%CE%95 "Ε"), [γ](/wiki/%CE%93 "Γ"), and
[μ](/wiki/%CE%9C "Μ").[2] The type of heavy chain present defines the _class_
of antibody; these chains are found in IgA, IgD, IgE, IgG, and IgM antibodies,
respectively.[1] Distinct heavy chains differ in size and composition; α and γ
contain approximately 450 amino acids, whereas μ and ε have approximately 550
[amino acids](/wiki/Amino_acid "Amino acid").[2]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Immunoglobulin_basic_unit.svg/220px-
Immunoglobulin_basic_unit.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Immunoglobulin_basic_unit.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Immunoglobulin_basic_unit.svg "Enlarge")

  1. [Fab region](/wiki/Fragment_antigen_binding "Fragment antigen binding")
  2. [Fc region](/wiki/Fragment_crystallizable_region "Fragment crystallizable region")
  3. [Heavy chain](/wiki/Immunoglobulin_heavy_chain "Immunoglobulin heavy chain") (blue) with one variable (VH) domain followed by a constant domain (CH1), a hinge region, and two more constant (CH2 and CH3) domains
  4. [Light chain](/wiki/Immunoglobulin_light_chain "Immunoglobulin light chain") (green) with one variable (VL) and one constant (CL) domain
  5. Antigen binding site (paratope)
  6. Hinge regions

Each heavy chain has two regions, the _constant region_ and the _variable
region_. The constant region is identical in all antibodies of the same
isotype, but differs in antibodies of different isotypes. Heavy chains γ, α
and δ have a constant region composed of _three_ tandem (in a line) Ig
[domains](/wiki/Structural_domain "Structural domain"), and a hinge region for
added flexibility;[14] heavy chains μ and ε have a constant region composed of
_four_ immunoglobulin domains.[2] The variable region of the heavy chain
differs in antibodies produced by different B cells, but is the same for all
antibodies produced by a single B cell or [B cell
clone](/wiki/Clone_\(B-cell_biology\) "Clone \(B-cell biology\)"). The
variable region of each heavy chain is approximately 110 amino acids long and
is composed of a single Ig domain.

### Light chain[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Light chain")]

For more details on this topic, see [Immunoglobulin light
chain](/wiki/Immunoglobulin_light_chain "Immunoglobulin light chain").

In mammals there are two types of [immunoglobulin light
chain](/wiki/Immunoglobulin_light_chain "Immunoglobulin light chain"), which
are called [lambda](/wiki/Lambda "Lambda") (λ) and [kappa](/wiki/Kappa
"Kappa") (κ).[2] A light chain has two successive domains: one constant domain
and one variable domain. The approximate length of a light chain is 211 to 217
amino acids.[2] Each antibody contains two light chains that are always
identical; only one type of light chain, κ or λ, is present per antibody in
mammals. Other types of light chains, such as the [iota](/wiki/Iota "Iota")
(ι) chain, are found in other [vertebrates](/wiki/Vertebrate "Vertebrate")
like sharks ([Chondrichthyes](/wiki/Chondrichthyes "Chondrichthyes")) and bony
fishes ([Teleostei](/wiki/Teleostei "Teleostei")).

### CDRs, Fv, Fab and Fc
regions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: CDRs, Fv, Fab and Fc regions")]

Some parts of an antibody have the same functions. The arms of the Y, for
example, contain the sites that can bind to antigens (in general, identical)
and, therefore, recognize specific foreign objects. This region of the
antibody is called the _[Fab (fragment, antigen-binding)
region](/wiki/Fab_region "Fab region")_. It is composed of one constant and
one variable domain from each heavy and light chain of the antibody.[24] The
[paratope](/wiki/Paratope "Paratope") is shaped at the [amino terminal
end](/wiki/N-terminal_end "N-terminal end") of the antibody
[monomer](/wiki/Monomer "Monomer") by the variable domains from the heavy and
light chains. The variable domain is also referred to as the FV region and is
the most important region for binding to antigens. To be specific, variable
loops of β-strands, there each on the light (VL) and heavy (VH) chains are
responsible for binding to the antigen. These loops are referred to as the
[complementarity determining regions](/wiki/Complementarity_determining_region
"Complementarity determining region") (CDRs). The structures of these CDRs
have been clustered and classified by Chothia et al.[25] and more recently by
North et al.[26] and Nikoloudis et al.[27] In the framework of the [immune
network theory](/wiki/Immune_network_theory "Immune network theory"), CDRs are
also called idiotypes. According to immune network theory, the adaptive immune
system is regulated by interactions between idiotypes.

The base of the Y plays a role in modulating immune cell activity. This region
is called the _[Fc (Fragment, crystallizable) region](/wiki/Fc_region "Fc
region")_ , and is composed of two heavy chains that contribute two or three
constant domains depending on the class of the antibody.[2] Thus, the Fc
region ensures that each antibody generates an appropriate immune response for
a given antigen, by binding to a specific class of [Fc
receptors](/wiki/Fc_receptor "Fc receptor"), and other immune molecules, such
as [complement](/wiki/Complement_system "Complement system") proteins. By
doing this, it mediates different [physiological](/wiki/Physiological
"Physiological") effects including recognition of
[opsonized](/wiki/Opsonization "Opsonization") particles (binding to FcγR),
[lysis](/wiki/Lysis "Lysis") of cells (binding to complement), and
[degranulation](/wiki/Degranulation "Degranulation") of [mast
cells](/wiki/Mast_cell "Mast cell"), [basophils](/wiki/Basophil "Basophil"),
and [eosinophils](/wiki/Eosinophil "Eosinophil") (binding to FcεR).[14][28]

In summary, the Fab region of the antibody determines antigen specificity
while the Fc region of the antibody determines the antibody's class effect.
Since only the constant domains of the heavy chains make up the Fc region of
an antibody, the classes of heavy chain in antibodies determine their class
effects. Possible classes of heavy chains in antibodies include alpha, gamma,
delta, epsilon, and mu, and they define the antibody's isotypes IgA, G, D, E,
and M, respectively. This infers different isotypes of antibodies have
different class effects due to their different Fc regions binding and
activating different types of receptors. Possible class effects of antibodies
include: Opsonisation, agglutination, haemolysis, complement activation, mast
cell degranulation, and neutralisation (though this class effect may be
mediated by the Fab region rather than the Fc region). It also implies that
Fab-mediated effects are directed at microbes or toxins, whilst Fc mediated
effects are directed at effector cells or effector molecules (see below).

## Function[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Function")]

Further information: [Immune system](/wiki/Immune_system "Immune system")

The main categories of antibody action include the following:

  * [Neutralisation](/wiki/Neutralisation_\(immunology\) "Neutralisation \(immunology\)"), in which [neutralizing antibodies](/wiki/Neutralizing_antibody "Neutralizing antibody") block parts of the surface of a bacterial cell or virion to render its attack ineffective
  * [Agglutination](/wiki/Agglutination_\(biology\) "Agglutination \(biology\)"), in which antibodies "glue together" foreign cells into clumps that are attractive targets for [phagocytosis](/wiki/Phagocytosis "Phagocytosis")
  * [Precipitation](/wiki/Precipitation_\(chemistry\) "Precipitation \(chemistry\)"), in which antibodies "glue together" [serum](/wiki/Blood_serum "Blood serum")-soluble antigens, forcing them to precipitate out of solution in clumps that are attractive targets for [phagocytosis](/wiki/Phagocytosis "Phagocytosis")
  * [Complement activation](/wiki/Complement_system#Overview "Complement system") (fixation), in which antibodies that are latched onto a foreign cell encourage complement to attack it with a [membrane attack complex](/wiki/Membrane_attack_complex "Membrane attack complex"), which leads to the following: 
    * [Lysis](/wiki/Lysis "Lysis") of the foreign cell
    * Encouragement of [inflammation](/wiki/Inflammation "Inflammation") by [chemotactically](/wiki/Chemotaxis "Chemotaxis") attracting inflammatory cells

Activated B cells [differentiate](/wiki/Cellular_differentiation "Cellular
differentiation") into either antibody-producing cells called [plasma
cells](/wiki/Plasma_cell "Plasma cell") that secrete soluble antibody or
[memory cells](/wiki/Memory_B_cell "Memory B cell") that survive in the body
for years afterward in order to allow the immune system to remember an antigen
and respond faster upon future exposures.[29]

At the [prenatal](/wiki/Prenatal "Prenatal") and neonatal stages of life, the
presence of antibodies is provided by [passive
immunization](/wiki/Passive_immunization "Passive immunization") from the
mother. Early endogenous antibody production varies for different kinds of
antibodies, and usually appear within the first years of life. Since
antibodies exist freely in the bloodstream, they are said to be part of the
[humoral immune system](/wiki/Humoral_immune_system "Humoral immune system").
Circulating antibodies are produced by clonal B cells that specifically
respond to only one [antigen](/wiki/Antigen "Antigen") (an example is a
[virus](/wiki/Virus "Virus") [capsid protein](/wiki/Capsid "Capsid")
fragment). Antibodies contribute to [immunity](/wiki/Immunity_\(medical\)
"Immunity \(medical\)") in three ways: They prevent pathogens from entering or
damaging cells by binding to them; they stimulate removal of pathogens by
[macrophages](/wiki/Macrophages "Macrophages") and other cells by coating the
pathogen; and they trigger destruction of pathogens by stimulating other
[immune responses](/wiki/Immune_response "Immune response") such as the
[complement pathway](/wiki/Complement_system "Complement system").[30]
Antibodies will also trigger vasoactive amine degranulation to contribute to
immunity against certain types of antigens (helminths, allergens).

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/IgM_white_background.png/220px-
IgM_white_background.png)](/wiki/File:IgM_white_background.png)

[](/wiki/File:IgM_white_background.png "Enlarge")

The secreted mammalian [IgM](/wiki/IgM "IgM") has five Ig units. Each Ig unit
(labeled 1) has two epitope binding [Fab regions](/wiki/Fab_region "Fab
region"), so IgM is capable of binding up to 10 epitopes.

### Activation of
complement[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Activation of complement")]

Antibodies that bind to surface antigens (for example, on bacteria) will
attract the first component of the [complement
cascade](/wiki/Complement_cascade "Complement cascade") with their [Fc
region](/wiki/Fv_region "Fv region") and initiate activation of the
"classical" complement system.[30] This results in the killing of bacteria in
two ways.[5] First, the binding of the antibody and complement molecules marks
the microbe for ingestion by [phagocytes](/wiki/Phagocyte "Phagocyte") in a
process called [opsonization](/wiki/Opsonization "Opsonization"); these
phagocytes are attracted by certain complement molecules generated in the
complement cascade. Second, some complement system components form a [membrane
attack complex](/wiki/Complement_membrane_attack_complex "Complement membrane
attack complex") to assist antibodies to kill the bacterium directly
(bacteriolysis).[31]

### Activation of effector
cells[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section:
Activation of effector cells")]

To combat pathogens that replicate outside cells, antibodies bind to pathogens
to link them together, causing them to
[agglutinate](/wiki/Agglutination_\(biology\) "Agglutination \(biology\)").
Since an antibody has at least two paratopes, it can bind more than one
antigen by binding identical epitopes carried on the surfaces of these
antigens. By coating the pathogen, antibodies stimulate effector functions
against the pathogen in cells that recognize their Fc region.[5]

Those cells that recognize coated pathogens have Fc receptors, which, as the
name suggests, interact with the [Fc region](/wiki/Fc_region "Fc region") of
IgA, IgG, and IgE antibodies. The engagement of a particular antibody with the
Fc receptor on a particular cell triggers an effector function of that cell;
phagocytes will [phagocytose](/wiki/Phagocytosis "Phagocytosis"), [mast
cells](/wiki/Mast_cell "Mast cell") and [neutrophils](/wiki/Neutrophil
"Neutrophil") will [degranulate](/wiki/Degranulation "Degranulation"),
[natural killer cells](/wiki/Natural_killer_cell "Natural killer cell") will
release [cytokines](/wiki/Cytokine "Cytokine") and [cytotoxic](/wiki/Cytotoxic
"Cytotoxic") molecules; that will ultimately result in destruction of the
invading microbe. The activation of natural killer cells by antibodies
initiates a cytotoxic mechanism known as [antibody-dependent cell-mediated
cytotoxicity](/wiki/Antibody-dependent_cell-mediated_cytotoxicity "Antibody-
dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity") (ADCC) – this process may explain the
efficacy of [monoclonal antibodies](/wiki/Monoclonal_antibody "Monoclonal
antibody") used in [biological](/wiki/Biopharmaceutical "Biopharmaceutical")
therapies against [cancer](/wiki/Cancer "Cancer"). The Fc receptors are
isotype-specific, which gives greater flexibility to the immune system,
invoking only the appropriate immune mechanisms for distinct pathogens.[2]

### Natural
antibodies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Natural antibodies")]

Humans and higher primates also produce "natural antibodies" that are present
in serum before viral infection. Natural antibodies have been defined as
antibodies that are produced without any previous infection, vaccination,
other foreign antigen exposure or [passive
immunization](/wiki/Passive_immunization "Passive immunization"). These
antibodies can activate the classical complement pathway leading to lysis of
enveloped virus particles long before the adaptive immune response is
activated. Many natural antibodies are directed against the disaccharide
[galactose](/wiki/Galactose "Galactose") α(1,3)-galactose (α-Gal), which is
found as a terminal sugar on [glycosylated](/wiki/Glycosylation
"Glycosylation") cell surface proteins, and generated in response to
production of this sugar by bacteria contained in the human gut.[32] Rejection
of [xenotransplantated organs](/wiki/Organ_xenotransplantation "Organ
xenotransplantation") is thought to be, in part, the result of natural
antibodies circulating in the serum of the recipient binding to α-Gal antigens
expressed on the donor tissue.[33]

## Immunoglobulin
diversity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Immunoglobulin diversity")]

Virtually all microbes can trigger an antibody response. Successful
recognition and eradication of many different types of microbes requires
diversity among antibodies; their amino acid composition varies allowing them
to interact with many different antigens.[34] It has been estimated that
humans generate about 10 billion different antibodies, each capable of binding
a distinct epitope of an antigen.[35] Although a huge repertoire of different
antibodies is generated in a single individual, the number of
[genes](/wiki/Gene "Gene") available to make these proteins is limited by the
size of the human genome. Several complex genetic mechanisms have evolved that
allow vertebrate B cells to generate a diverse pool of antibodies from a
relatively small number of antibody genes.[36]

### Domain
variability[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Domain variability")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Complementarity_determining_regions.PNG/250px-
Complementarity_determining_regions.PNG)](/wiki/File:Complementarity_determining_regions.PNG)

[](/wiki/File:Complementarity_determining_regions.PNG "Enlarge")

The complementarity determining regions of the heavy chain are shown in red
([PDB](/wiki/Protein_Data_Bank "Protein Data Bank"):
[1IGT](http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/explore/explore.do?structureId=1IGT)​)

The chromosomal region that encodes an antibody is large and contains several
distinct gene loci for each domain of the antibody—the chromosome region
containing heavy chain genes ([IGH@](/wiki/IGH@ "IGH@")) is found on
[chromosome 14](/wiki/Chromosome_14 "Chromosome 14"), and the loci containing
lambda and kappa light chain genes ([IGL@](/wiki/IGL@ "IGL@") and
[IGK@](/wiki/IGK@ "IGK@")) are found on chromosomes [22](/wiki/Chromosome_22
"Chromosome 22") and [2](/wiki/Chromosome_2 "Chromosome 2") in humans. One of
these domains is called the variable domain, which is present in each heavy
and light chain of every antibody, but can differ in different antibodies
generated from distinct B cells. Differences, between the variable domains,
are located on three loops known as hypervariable regions (HV-1, HV-2 and
HV-3) or [complementarity determining
regions](/wiki/Complementarity_determining_region "Complementarity determining
region") (CDR1, CDR2 and CDR3). CDRs are supported within the variable domains
by conserved framework regions. The heavy chain locus contains about 65
different variable domain genes that all differ in their CDRs. Combining these
genes with an array of genes for other domains of the antibody generates a
large cavalry of antibodies with a high degree of variability. This
combination is called V(D)J recombination discussed below.[37]

### V(D)J
recombination[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: V\(D\)J recombination")]

For more details on this topic, see [V(D)J
recombination](/wiki/V\(D\)J_recombination "V\(D\)J recombination").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/VDJ_recombination.png/250px-
VDJ_recombination.png)](/wiki/File:VDJ_recombination.png)

[](/wiki/File:VDJ_recombination.png "Enlarge")

Simplified overview of V(D)J recombination of immunoglobulin heavy chains

Somatic recombination of immunoglobulins, also known as _V(D)J recombination_
, involves the generation of a unique immunoglobulin variable region. The
variable region of each immunoglobulin heavy or light chain is encoded in
several pieces—known as gene segments (subgenes). These segments are called
variable (V), diversity (D) and joining (J) segments.[36] V, D and J segments
are found in [Ig heavy chains](/wiki/Immunoglobulin_heavy_chain
"Immunoglobulin heavy chain"), but only V and J segments are found in [Ig
light chains](/wiki/Immunoglobulin_light_chain "Immunoglobulin light chain").
Multiple copies of the V, D and J gene segments exist, and are tandemly
arranged in the [genomes](/wiki/Genome "Genome") of [mammals](/wiki/Mammal
"Mammal"). In the bone marrow, each developing B cell will assemble an
immunoglobulin variable region by randomly selecting and combining one V, one
D and one J gene segment (or one V and one J segment in the light chain). As
there are multiple copies of each type of gene segment, and different
combinations of gene segments can be used to generate each immunoglobulin
variable region, this process generates a huge number of antibodies, each with
different [paratopes](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/paratope
"wikt:paratope"), and thus different antigen specificities.[8] Interestingly,
the rearrangement of several subgenes (i.e. V2 family) for lambda light chain
immunoglobulin is coupled with the activation of microRNA miR-650, which
further influences biology of B-cells.[38]

RAG proteins play an important role with V(D)J recombination in cutting DNA at
a particular region.[39] Without the presence of these proteins, V(D)J
recombination would not occur.[39]

After a B cell produces a functional immunoglobulin gene during V(D)J
recombination, it cannot express any other variable region (a process known as
[allelic exclusion](/wiki/Allelic_exclusion "Allelic exclusion")) thus each B
cell can produce antibodies containing only one kind of variable chain.[2][40]

### Somatic hypermutation and affinity
maturation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: Somatic hypermutation and affinity maturation")]

Further information: [Somatic hypermutation](/wiki/Somatic_hypermutation
"Somatic hypermutation") and [Affinity maturation](/wiki/Affinity_maturation
"Affinity maturation")

Following activation with antigen, B cells begin to
[proliferate](/wiki/Cell_division "Cell division") rapidly. In these rapidly
dividing cells, the genes encoding the variable domains of the heavy and light
chains undergo a high rate of [point mutation](/wiki/Point_mutation "Point
mutation"), by a process called _somatic hypermutation_ (SHM). SHM results in
approximately one [nucleotide](/wiki/Nucleotide "Nucleotide") change per
variable gene, per cell division.[10] As a consequence, any daughter B cells
will acquire slight [amino acid](/wiki/Amino_acid "Amino acid") differences in
the variable domains of their antibody chains.

This serves to increase the diversity of the antibody pool and impacts the
antibody's antigen-binding [affinity](/wiki/Chemical_affinity "Chemical
affinity").[41] Some point mutations will result in the production of
antibodies that have a weaker interaction (low affinity) with their antigen
than the original antibody, and some mutations will generate antibodies with a
stronger interaction (high affinity).[42] B cells that express high affinity
antibodies on their surface will receive a strong survival signal during
interactions with other cells, whereas those with low affinity antibodies will
not, and will die by [apoptosis](/wiki/Apoptosis "Apoptosis").[42] Thus, B
cells expressing antibodies with a higher affinity for the antigen will
outcompete those with weaker affinities for function and survival allowing the
average affinity of antibodies to increase over time. The process of
generating antibodies with increased binding affinities is called _affinity
maturation_. Affinity maturation occurs in mature B cells after V(D)J
recombination, and is dependent on help from [helper T
cells](/wiki/Helper_T_cell "Helper T cell").[43]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Class_switch_recombination.png/250px-
Class_switch_recombination.png)](/wiki/File:Class_switch_recombination.png)

[](/wiki/File:Class_switch_recombination.png "Enlarge")

Mechanism of class switch recombination that allows isotype switching in
activated B cells

### Class switching[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Class switching")]

[Isotype or class switching](/wiki/Immunoglobulin_class_switching
"Immunoglobulin class switching") is a [biological
process](/wiki/Biological_process "Biological process") occurring after
activation of the B cell, which allows the cell to produce different classes
of antibody (IgA, IgE, or IgG).[8] The different classes of antibody, and thus
effector functions, are defined by the constant (C) regions of the
immunoglobulin heavy chain. Initially, naive B cells express only cell-surface
IgM and IgD with identical antigen binding regions. Each isotype is adapted
for a distinct function; therefore, after activation, an antibody with an IgG,
IgA, or IgE effector function might be required to effectively eliminate an
antigen. Class switching allows different daughter cells from the same
activated B cell to produce antibodies of different isotypes. Only the
constant region of the antibody heavy chain changes during class switching;
the variable regions, and therefore antigen specificity, remain unchanged.
Thus the progeny of a single B cell can produce antibodies, all specific for
the same antigen, but with the ability to produce the effector function
appropriate for each antigenic challenge. Class switching is triggered by
cytokines; the isotype generated depends on which cytokines are present in the
B cell environment.[44]

Class switching occurs in the heavy chain gene
[locus](/wiki/Locus_\(genetics\) "Locus \(genetics\)") by a mechanism called
class switch recombination (CSR). This mechanism relies on conserved
[nucleotide](/wiki/Nucleotide "Nucleotide") motifs, called _switch (S)
regions_ , found in [DNA](/wiki/DNA "DNA") upstream of each constant region
gene (except in the δ-chain). The DNA strand is broken by the activity of a
series of [enzymes](/wiki/Enzyme "Enzyme") at two selected S-regions.[45][46]
The variable domain [exon](/wiki/Exon "Exon") is rejoined through a process
called [non-homologous end joining](/wiki/Non-homologous_end_joining "Non-
homologous end joining") (NHEJ) to the desired constant region (γ, α or ε).
This process results in an immunoglobulin gene that encodes an antibody of a
different isotype.[47]

### Affinity
designations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=18 "Edit
section: Affinity designations")]

A group of antibodies can be called _monovalent_ (or _specific_) if they have
affinity for the same epitope,[48] or for the same antigen[49] (but
potentially different epitopes on the molecule), or for the same strain of
microorganism[49] (but potentially different antigens on or in it). In
contrast, a group of antibodies can be called _polyvalent_ (or _unspecific_)
if they have affinity for various antigens[50] or microorganisms.[50]
[Intravenous immunoglobulin](/wiki/Intravenous_immunoglobulin "Intravenous
immunoglobulin"), if not otherwise noted, consists of polyvalent IgG. In
contrast, [monoclonal antibodies](/wiki/Monoclonal_antibodies "Monoclonal
antibodies") are monovalent for the same epitope.

### Asymmetrical
antibodies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: Asymmetrical antibodies")]

Heterodimeric antibodies, which are also asymmetrical and antibodies, allow
for greater flexibility and new formats for attaching a variety of drugs to
the antibody arms. One of the general formats for a heterodimeric antibody is
the “knobs-into-holes” format. This format is specific to the heavy chain part
of the constant region in antibodies. The “knobs” part is engineered by
replacing a small amino acid with a larger one. It fits into the “hole”, which
is engineered by replacing a large amino acid with a smaller one. What
connects the “knobs” to the “holes” are the disulfide bonds between each
chain. The “knobs-into-holes” shape facilitates antibody dependent cell
mediated cytotoxicity. [Single chain variable fragments](/wiki/Single-
chain_variable_fragment "Single-chain variable fragment") ([scFv](/wiki/ScFv
"ScFv")) are connected to the variable domain of the heavy and light chain via
a short linker peptide. The linker is rich in glycine, which gives it more
flexibility, and serine/threonine, which gives it specificity. Two different
scFv fragments can be connected together, via a hinge region, to the constant
domain of the heavy chain or the constant domain of the light chain.[51] This
gives the antibody bispecificity, allowing for the binding specificities of
two different antigens.[52] The “knobs-into-holes” format enhances heterodimer
formation but doesn’t suppress homodimer formation.

To further improve the function of heterodimeric antibodies, many scientists
are looking towards artificial constructs. Artificial antibodies are largely
diverse protein motifs that use the functional strategy of the antibody
molecule, but aren’t limited by the loop and framework structural constraints
of the natural antibody.[53] Being able to control the combinational design of
the sequence and three-dimensional space could transcend the natural design
and allow for the attachment of different combinations of drugs to the arms.

Heterodimeric antibodies have a greater range in shapes they can take and the
drugs that are attached to the arms don’t have to be the same on each arm,
allowing for different combinations of drugs to be used in cancer treatment.
Pharmaceuticals are able to produce highly functional bispecific, and even
multispecific, antibodies. The degree to which they can function is impressive
given that such a change shape from the natural form should lead to decreased
functionality.

## Medical
applications[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=20 "Edit
section: Medical applications")]

### Disease
diagnosis[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=21 "Edit
section: Disease diagnosis")]

Detection of particular antibodies is a very common form of medical
[diagnostics](/wiki/Medical_diagnosis "Medical diagnosis"), and applications
such as [serology](/wiki/Serology "Serology") depend on these methods.[54] For
example, in biochemical assays for disease diagnosis,[55] a
[titer](/wiki/Titer "Titer") of antibodies directed against [Epstein-Barr
virus](/wiki/Epstein-Barr_virus "Epstein-Barr virus") or [Lyme
disease](/wiki/Lyme_disease "Lyme disease") is estimated from the blood. If
those antibodies are not present, either the person is not infected or the
infection occurred a _very_ long time ago, and the B cells generating these
specific antibodies have naturally decayed.

In [clinical immunology](/wiki/Clinical_immunology "Clinical immunology"),
levels of individual classes of immunoglobulins are measured by
[nephelometry](/wiki/Nephelometry "Nephelometry") (or turbidimetry) to
characterize the antibody profile of patient.[56] Elevations in different
classes of immunoglobulins are sometimes useful in determining the cause of
[liver](/wiki/Liver "Liver") damage in patients for whom the diagnosis is
unclear.[1] For example, elevated IgA indicates alcoholic
[cirrhosis](/wiki/Cirrhosis "Cirrhosis"), elevated IgM indicates [viral
hepatitis](/wiki/Viral_hepatitis "Viral hepatitis") and [primary biliary
cirrhosis](/wiki/Primary_biliary_cirrhosis "Primary biliary cirrhosis"), while
IgG is elevated in viral hepatitis, [autoimmune
hepatitis](/wiki/Autoimmune_hepatitis "Autoimmune hepatitis") and cirrhosis.

[Autoimmune disorders](/wiki/Autoimmune_disorder "Autoimmune disorder") can
often be traced to antibodies that bind the body's own
[epitopes](/wiki/Epitope "Epitope"); many can be detected through [blood
tests](/wiki/Blood_test "Blood test"). Antibodies directed against [red blood
cell](/wiki/Red_blood_cell "Red blood cell") surface antigens in immune
mediated [hemolytic anemia](/wiki/Hemolytic_anemia "Hemolytic anemia") are
detected with the [Coombs test](/wiki/Coombs_test "Coombs test").[57] The
Coombs test is also used for antibody screening in [blood
transfusion](/wiki/Blood_transfusion "Blood transfusion") preparation and also
for antibody screening in [antenatal](/wiki/Antenatal "Antenatal") women.[57]

Practically, several immunodiagnostic methods based on detection of complex
antigen-antibody are used to diagnose infectious diseases, for example
[ELISA](/wiki/ELISA "ELISA"), [immunofluorescence](/wiki/Immunofluorescence
"Immunofluorescence"), [Western blot](/wiki/Western_blot "Western blot"),
[immunodiffusion](/wiki/Immunodiffusion "Immunodiffusion"),
[immunoelectrophoresis](/wiki/Immunoelectrophoresis "Immunoelectrophoresis"),
and [magnetic immunoassay](/wiki/Magnetic_immunoassay "Magnetic immunoassay").
Antibodies raised against human chorionic gonadotropin are used in over the
counter pregnancy tests.

New dioxaborolane chemistry enables radioactive [fluoride](/wiki/Fluoride
"Fluoride") ([18F](/wiki/Fluorine-18 "Fluorine-18")) labeling of antibodies,
which allows for [positron emission
tomography](/wiki/Positron_emission_tomography "Positron emission tomography")
(PET) imaging of [cancer](/wiki/Cancer "Cancer").[58]

### Disease therapy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Disease therapy")]

Targeted [monoclonal antibody therapy](/wiki/Monoclonal_antibody_therapy
"Monoclonal antibody therapy") is employed to treat diseases such as
[rheumatoid arthritis](/wiki/Rheumatoid_arthritis "Rheumatoid arthritis"),[59]
[multiple sclerosis](/wiki/Multiple_sclerosis "Multiple sclerosis"),[60]
[psoriasis](/wiki/Psoriasis "Psoriasis"),[61] and many forms of
[cancer](/wiki/Cancer "Cancer") including [non-Hodgkin's lymphoma](/wiki/Non-
Hodgkin%27s_lymphoma "Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma"),[62] [colorectal
cancer](/wiki/Colorectal_cancer "Colorectal cancer"), [head and neck
cancer](/wiki/Head_and_neck_cancer "Head and neck cancer") and [breast
cancer](/wiki/Breast_cancer "Breast cancer").[63]

Some immune deficiencies, such as [X-linked
agammaglobulinemia](/wiki/X-linked_agammaglobulinemia "X-linked
agammaglobulinemia") and [hypogammaglobulinemia](/wiki/Hypogammaglobulinemia
"Hypogammaglobulinemia"), result in partial or complete lack of
antibodies.[64] These diseases are often treated by inducing a short term form
of [immunity](/wiki/Immunity_\(medical\) "Immunity \(medical\)") called
[passive immunity](/wiki/Passive_immunity "Passive immunity"). Passive
immunity is achieved through the transfer of ready-made antibodies in the form
of human or animal [serum](/wiki/Blood_plasma "Blood plasma"), pooled
immunoglobulin or monoclonal antibodies, into the affected individual.[65]

### Prenatal therapy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Prenatal therapy")]

[Rh factor](/wiki/Rh_factor "Rh factor"), also known as Rh D antigen, is an
antigen found on [red blood cells](/wiki/Red_blood_cell "Red blood cell");
individuals that are Rh-positive (Rh+) have this antigen on their red blood
cells and individuals that are Rh-negative (Rh–) do not. During normal
[childbirth](/wiki/Childbirth "Childbirth"), delivery trauma or complications
during pregnancy, blood from a [fetus](/wiki/Fetus "Fetus") can enter the
mother's system. In the case of an Rh-incompatible mother and child,
consequential blood mixing may sensitize an Rh- mother to the Rh antigen on
the blood cells of the Rh+ child, putting the remainder of the
[pregnancy](/wiki/Pregnancy "Pregnancy"), and any subsequent pregnancies, at
risk for [hemolytic disease of the
newborn](/wiki/Hemolytic_disease_of_the_newborn "Hemolytic disease of the
newborn").[66]

[Rho(D) immune globulin](/wiki/Rho\(D\)_immune_globulin "Rho\(D\) immune
globulin") antibodies are specific for human RhD antigen.[67] Anti-RhD
antibodies are administered as part of a [prenatal treatment
regimen](/wiki/Prenatal_care "Prenatal care") to prevent sensitization that
may occur when a Rh-negative mother has a Rh-positive fetus. Treatment of a
mother with Anti-RhD antibodies prior to and immediately after trauma and
delivery destroys Rh antigen in the mother's system from the fetus. It is
important to note that this occurs before the antigen can stimulate maternal B
cells to "remember" Rh antigen by generating memory B cells. Therefore, her
humoral immune system will not make anti-Rh antibodies, and will not attack
the Rh antigens of the current or subsequent babies. Rho(D) Immune Globulin
treatment prevents sensitization that can lead to [Rh
disease](/wiki/Rh_disease "Rh disease"), but does not prevent or treat the
underlying disease itself.[67]

## Research
applications[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=24 "Edit
section: Research applications")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/FluorescentCells.jpg/200px-
FluorescentCells.jpg)](/wiki/File:FluorescentCells.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:FluorescentCells.jpg "Enlarge")

[Immunofluorescence](/wiki/Immunofluorescence "Immunofluorescence") image of
the eukaryotic [cytoskeleton](/wiki/Cytoskeleton "Cytoskeleton").
[Microtubules](/wiki/Microtubule "Microtubule") as shown in green, are marked
by an antibody conjugated to a green fluorescing molecule,
[FITC](/wiki/Fluorescein_isothiocyanate "Fluorescein isothiocyanate").

Specific antibodies are produced by injecting an [antigen](/wiki/Antigen
"Antigen") into a [mammal](/wiki/Mammal "Mammal"), such as a
[mouse](/wiki/Mouse "Mouse"), [rat](/wiki/Rat "Rat"), [rabbit](/wiki/Rabbit
"Rabbit"), [goat](/wiki/Goat "Goat"), [sheep](/wiki/Sheep "Sheep"), or
[horse](/wiki/Horse "Horse") for large quantities of antibody. Blood isolated
from these animals contains _[polyclonal
antibodies](/wiki/Polyclonal_antibodies "Polyclonal antibodies")_ —multiple
antibodies that bind to the same antigen—in the [serum](/wiki/Blood_plasma
"Blood plasma"), which can now be called [antiserum](/wiki/Antiserum
"Antiserum"). Antigens are also injected into [chickens](/wiki/Chicken
"Chicken") for generation of polyclonal antibodies in [egg
yolk](/wiki/Egg_yolk "Egg yolk").[68] To obtain antibody that is specific for
a single epitope of an antigen, antibody-secreting
[lymphocytes](/wiki/Lymphocyte "Lymphocyte") are isolated from the animal and
[immortalized](/wiki/Biological_immortality "Biological immortality") by
fusing them with a cancer cell line. The fused cells are called
[hybridomas](/wiki/Hybridoma "Hybridoma"), and will continually grow and
secrete antibody in culture. Single hybridoma cells are isolated by [dilution
cloning](/wiki/Dilution_cloning "Dilution cloning") to generate [cell
clones](/wiki/Cloning#Cellular_cloning "Cloning") that all produce the same
antibody; these antibodies are called _[monoclonal
antibodies](/wiki/Monoclonal_antibodies "Monoclonal antibodies")_.[69]
Polyclonal and monoclonal antibodies are often purified using [Protein
A/G](/wiki/Protein_A/G "Protein A/G") or [antigen-affinity
chromatography](/wiki/Affinity_chromatography "Affinity chromatography").[70]

In research, purified antibodies are used in many applications. Antibodies for
research applications can be found directly from antibody suppliers, or
through use of a specialist search engine. Research antibodies are most
commonly used to identify and locate [intracellular](/wiki/Intracellular
"Intracellular") and [extracellular](/wiki/Extracellular "Extracellular")
proteins. Antibodies are used in [flow cytometry](/wiki/Flow_cytometry "Flow
cytometry") to differentiate cell types by the proteins they express;
different types of cell express different combinations of [cluster of
differentiation](/wiki/Cluster_of_differentiation "Cluster of
differentiation") molecules on their surface, and produce different
intracellular and secretable proteins.[71] They are also used in
[immunoprecipitation](/wiki/Immunoprecipitation "Immunoprecipitation") to
separate proteins and anything bound to them (co-immunoprecipitation) from
other molecules in a [cell lysate](/wiki/Cell_lysate "Cell lysate"),[72] in
[Western blot](/wiki/Western_blot "Western blot") analyses to identify
proteins separated by [electrophoresis](/wiki/Electrophoresis
"Electrophoresis"),[73] and in
[immunohistochemistry](/wiki/Immunohistochemistry "Immunohistochemistry") or
[immunofluorescence](/wiki/Immunofluorescence "Immunofluorescence") to examine
protein expression in tissue sections or to locate proteins within cells with
the assistance of a [microscope](/wiki/Microscope "Microscope").[71][74]
Proteins can also be detected and quantified with antibodies, using
[ELISA](/wiki/ELISA "ELISA") and [ELISPOT](/wiki/ELISPOT "ELISPOT")
techniques.[75][76]

Antibodies used in research are some of the most powerful, yet most
problematic reagents with a tremendous number of factors that must be
controlled in any experiment including cross reactivity, or the antibody
recognizing multiple epitopes and affinity, which can vary widely depending on
experimental conditions such as pH, solvent, state of tissue etc. Multiple
attempts have been made to improve both the way that researchers validate
antibodies[77][78] and ways in which they report on antibodies. Researchers
using antibodies in their work need to record them correctly in order to allow
their research to be reproducible (and therefore tested, and qualified by
other researchers). Less than half of research antibodies referenced in
academic papers can be easily identified.[79] Papers published in
[F1000](/wiki/F1000 "F1000") in 2014 and 2015 provide researchers with a guide
for reporting research antibody use.[80][81] The RRID paper, is co-published
in 4 journals that implemented the [RRIDs](/wiki/RRIDs "RRIDs") Standard for
research resource citation, which draws data from the antibodyregistry.org as
the source of antibody identifiers[82] (see also group at Force11[83])

## Regulations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=25 "Edit
section: Regulations")]

### Production and
testing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=26 "Edit
section: Production and testing")]

Traditionally, most antibodies are produced by hybridoma
[cell](/wiki/Cell_\(biology\) "Cell \(biology\)") lines through
immortalization of antibody-producing cells by chemically-induced fusion with
myeloma cells. In some cases, additional fusions with other lines have created
"triomas" and "quadromas". The manufacturing process should be appropriately
described and validated. Validation studies should at least include :

  * The demonstration that the process is able to produce in good quality (the process should be validated)
  *   * The [efficiency](/wiki/Efficiency "Efficiency") of the antibody purification (all [impurities](/wiki/Impurities "Impurities") and [virus](/wiki/Virus "Virus") must be eliminated)
  *   * The characterization of purified antibody ([physicochemical](/wiki/Physical_chemistry "Physical chemistry") characterization, [immunological](/wiki/Immunological "Immunological") properties, [biological](/wiki/Biological "Biological") activities, contaminants, ...)
  * Determination of the virus clearance studies

### Before clinical
trials[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=27 "Edit
section: Before clinical trials")]

  * Product safety testing : Sterility (bacteria and fungi), In vitro and in vivo testing for adventitious viruses, Murine retrovirus testing... Product safety data needed before the initiation of feasibility trials in serious or immediately life-threatening conditions, it serves to evaluate dangerous potential of the product.
  * Feasibility testing : These are pilot studies whose objectives include, among others, early characterization of safety and initial proof of concept in a small specific patient population (in vito or in vivo testing).

### Preclinical
studies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=28 "Edit
section: Preclinical studies")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Example_of_tissue_cross-
reactivity_on_human_tissue_microarray.jpeg/220px-Example_of_tissue_cross-
reactivity_on_human_tissue_microarray.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Example_of_tissue_cross-
reactivity_on_human_tissue_microarray.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:Example_of_tissue_cross-
reactivity_on_human_tissue_microarray.jpeg "Enlarge")

Example of tissue cross-reactivity on human [tissue
microarray](/wiki/Tissue_microarray "Tissue microarray")

  * Testing [cross-reactivity](/wiki/Cross-reactivity "Cross-reactivity") of antibody : to highlight unwanted interactions (toxicity) of antibodies with previously characterized tissues. This study can be performed in vitro (Reactivity of the antibody or immunoconjugate should be determined with a quick-frozen adult tissues) or in vivo (with appropriates animal models). [More informations about in vitro cross-reactivity testing.](http://www.histalim.com/accueil/activities/our-expert-services/?lang=en)
  * Preclinical [pharmacology](/wiki/Pharmacology "Pharmacology") and [toxicity](/wiki/Toxicity "Toxicity") testing : [Preclinical](/wiki/Preclinical "Preclinical") safety testing of antibody is designed to identify possible toxicities in humans, to estimate the likelihood and severity of potential adverse events in humans, and to identify a safe starting dose and dose escalation, when possible.
  * Animal toxicity studies : Acute toxicity testing, Repeat-dose toxicity testing, Long-term toxicity testing <http://www.animalresearch.info/en/drug-development/safety-testing/>
  * Pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics testing : Use for determinate clinical dosages, antibody activities (AUC, pharmacodynamics, biodistribution, ...), evaluation of the potential clinical effects

## Structure
prediction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=29 "Edit
section: Structure prediction")]

The importance of antibodies in health care and the
[biotechnology](/wiki/Biotechnology "Biotechnology") industry demands
knowledge of their structures at [high resolution](/wiki/Image_resolution
"Image resolution"). This information is used for [protein
engineering](/wiki/Protein_engineering "Protein engineering"), modifying the
antigen binding affinity, and identifying an epitope, of a given antibody.
[X-ray crystallography](/wiki/X-ray_crystallography "X-ray crystallography")
is one commonly used method for determining antibody structures. However,
crystallizing an antibody is often laborious and time-consuming. Computational
approaches provide a cheaper and faster alternative to crystallography, but
their results are more equivocal, since they do not produce empirical
structures. Online web servers such as _Web Antibody Modeling_ (WAM)[84] and
_Prediction of Immunoglobulin Structure_ (PIGS)[85] enables computational
modeling of antibody variable regions. Rosetta Antibody is a novel antibody FV
region structure prediction [server](/wiki/Server_\(computing\) "Server
\(computing\)"), which incorporates sophisticated techniques to minimize CDR
loops and optimize the relative orientation of the light and heavy chains, as
well as [homology](/wiki/Homology_\(biology\) "Homology \(biology\)") models
that predict successful docking of antibodies with their unique antigen.[86]

The ability to describe the antibody through binding affinity to the antigen
is supplemented by information on antibody structure and amino acid sequences
for the purpose of patent claims.[87]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=30 "Edit
section: History")]

See also: [History of immunology](/wiki/History_of_immunology "History of
immunology")

The first use of the term "antibody" occurred in a text by [Paul
Ehrlich](/wiki/Paul_Ehrlich "Paul Ehrlich"). The term _Antikörper_ (the German
word for _antibody_) appears in the conclusion of his article "Experimental
Studies on Immunity", published in October 1891, which states that, "if two
substances give rise to two different antikörper, then they themselves must be
different".[88] However, the term was not accepted immediately and several
other terms for antibody were proposed; these included _Immunkörper_ ,
_Amboceptor_ , _Zwischenkörper_ , _substance sensibilisatrice_ , _copula_ ,
_Desmon_ , _philocytase_ , _fixateur_ , and _Immunisin_.[88] The word
_antibody_ has formal analogy to the word _[antitoxin](/wiki/Antitoxin
"Antitoxin")_ and a similar concept to _Immunkörper_ (_immune body_ in
English).[88] As such, the original construction of the word contains a
logical flaw; the antitoxin is something directed against a toxin, while the
antibody is a body directed against something.[88]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/AngeloftheWest.jpg/250px-
AngeloftheWest.jpg)](/wiki/File:AngeloftheWest.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:AngeloftheWest.jpg "Enlarge")

_[Angel of the West](/wiki/Angel_of_the_West "Angel of the West")_ (2008) by
[Julian Voss-Andreae](/wiki/Julian_Voss-Andreae "Julian Voss-Andreae") is a
sculpture based on the antibody structure published by E. Padlan.[89] Created
for the Florida campus of [the Scripps Research
Institute](/wiki/The_Scripps_Research_Institute "The Scripps Research
Institute"),[90] the antibody is placed into a ring referencing [Leonardo da
Vinci's](/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci "Leonardo da Vinci") _[Vitruvian
Man](/wiki/Vitruvian_Man "Vitruvian Man")_ thus highlighting the similarity of
the antibody and the human body.[91]

The study of antibodies began in 1890 when [Kitasato
Shibasaburō](/wiki/Kitasato_Shibasabur%C5%8D "Kitasato Shibasaburō") described
antibody activity against [diphtheria](/wiki/Diphtheria "Diphtheria") and
[tetanus toxins](/wiki/Tetanus_toxin "Tetanus toxin"). Kitasato put forward
the theory of [humoral immunity](/wiki/Humoral_immunity "Humoral immunity"),
proposing that a mediator in serum could react with a foreign antigen.[92][93]
His idea prompted Paul Ehrlich to propose the [side-chain theory](/wiki/Side-
chain_theory "Side-chain theory") for antibody and antigen interaction in
1897, when he hypothesized that receptors (described as "side-chains") on the
surface of cells could bind specifically to [toxins](/wiki/Toxin "Toxin") – in
a "lock-and-key" interaction – and that this binding reaction is the trigger
for the production of antibodies.[94] Other researchers believed that
antibodies existed freely in the blood and, in 1904, [Almroth
Wright](/wiki/Almroth_Wright "Almroth Wright") suggested that soluble
antibodies coated [bacteria](/wiki/Bacteria "Bacteria") to label them for
[phagocytosis](/wiki/Phagocytosis "Phagocytosis") and killing; a process that
he named [opsoninization](/wiki/Opsonin "Opsonin").[95]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Michael_Heidelberger_1954.jpg/200px-
Michael_Heidelberger_1954.jpg)](/wiki/File:Michael_Heidelberger_1954.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Michael_Heidelberger_1954.jpg "Enlarge")

Michael Heidelberger

In the 1920s, [Michael Heidelberger](/wiki/Michael_Heidelberger "Michael
Heidelberger") and [Oswald Avery](/wiki/Oswald_Avery "Oswald Avery") observed
that antigens could be precipitated by antibodies and went on to show that
antibodies are made of protein.[96] The biochemical properties of antigen-
antibody-binding interactions were examined in more detail in the late 1930s
by [John Marrack](/wiki/John_Marrack "John Marrack").[97] The next major
advance was in the 1940s, when [Linus Pauling](/wiki/Linus_Pauling "Linus
Pauling") confirmed the lock-and-key theory proposed by Ehrlich by showing
that the interactions between antibodies and antigens depend more on their
shape than their chemical composition.[98] In 1948, Astrid Fagreaus discovered
that B cells, in the form of [plasma cells](/wiki/Plasma_cell "Plasma cell"),
were responsible for generating antibodies.[99]

Further work concentrated on characterizing the structures of the antibody
proteins. A major advance in these structural studies was the discovery in the
early 1960s by [Gerald Edelman](/wiki/Gerald_Edelman "Gerald Edelman") and
Joseph Gally of the antibody [light chain](/wiki/Immunoglobulin_light_chain
"Immunoglobulin light chain"),[100] and their realization that this protein is
the same as the [Bence-Jones protein](/wiki/Bence-Jones_protein "Bence-Jones
protein") described in 1845 by [Henry Bence Jones](/wiki/Henry_Bence_Jones
"Henry Bence Jones").[101] Edelman went on to discover that antibodies are
composed of [disulfide bond](/wiki/Disulfide_bond "Disulfide bond")-linked
heavy and light chains. Around the same time, antibody-binding (Fab) and
antibody tail (Fc) regions of IgG were characterized by [Rodney
Porter](/wiki/Rodney_Porter "Rodney Porter").[102] Together, these scientists
deduced the structure and complete [amino acid](/wiki/Amino_acid "Amino acid")
sequence of IgG, a feat for which they were jointly awarded the 1972 [Nobel
Prize in Physiology or Medicine](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine
"Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine").[102] The Fv fragment was prepared
and characterized by David Givol.[103] While most of these early studies
focused on IgM and IgG, other immunoglobulin isotypes were identified in the
1960s: Thomas Tomasi discovered secretory antibody ([IgA](/wiki/IgA
"IgA"));[104] David S. Rowe and John L. Fahey discovered IgD;[105] and
[Kimishige Ishizaka](/wiki/Kimishige_Ishizaka "Kimishige Ishizaka") and Teruko
Ishizaka discovered [IgE](/wiki/IgE "IgE") and showed it was a class of
antibodies involved in allergic reactions.[106] In a landmark series of
experiments beginning in 1976, [Susumu Tonegawa](/wiki/Susumu_Tonegawa "Susumu
Tonegawa") showed that genetic material can rearrange itself to form the vast
array of available antibodies.[107]

## Antibody mimetic[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Antibody&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: Antibody mimetic")]

[Antibody mimetics](/wiki/Antibody_mimetic "Antibody mimetic") are organic
compounds that, like antibodies, can specifically bind antigens. They are
usually artificial peptides or proteins with a molar mass of about 3 to 20
kDa. Nucleic acids and small molecules are sometimes considered antibody
mimetics, but not artificial antibodies, antibody fragments and fusion
proteins are composed from these. Common advantages over antibodies are better
solubility, tissue penetration, stability towards heat and enzymes, and
comparatively low production costs. Antibody mimetics such as the
[Affimer](/wiki/Affimer "Affimer") and the [DARPin](/wiki/DARPin "DARPin")
have being developed and commercialised as research, diagnostic and
therapeutic agents.[108]
